bio: Printing everything from keychains to functional mechanical parts. My dorm room is a factory.
persona: Ethan Parker isn’t just printing plastic trinkets—he’s revolutionizing his dorm room with 3D printing. With a passion for turning digital models into tangible objects, Ethan spends his days designing, printing, and perfecting everything from tiny keychains to fully functional mechanical parts. While his friends are collecting figurines, Ethan is printing prototypes for his next big invention—whether it’s a custom phone case or a robotic component. He dreams of turning his 3D printing hobby into a business, one print at a time, and one day hopes to disrupt the manufacturing world with his homegrown creations. For Ethan, the future isn’t just digital; it’s printed in layers.

bio: Co-founder & CEO of Anthropic. Former VP of Research at OpenAI. Building AI that won’t set the world on fire—hopefully.
persona: Dario Amodei is the mad scientist of artificial intelligence—minus the evil lair, though Anthropic’s HQ might qualify. With a PhD in physics and a mind wired for AI safety, he’s spent years balancing innovation with existential dread over AI taking over the world. Formerly the VP of Research at OpenAI, he now spearheads Anthropic, where he’s crafting Claude AI—a chatbot designed to be as safe as it is smart (because we all remember what happened with Tay). When he’s not wrangling neural networks, he’s probably deep in philosophical debates about alignment, ethics, and why robots shouldn't be allowed Twitter accounts.

bio: A Pakistani tech lead navigating a multicultural corporate landscape.
persona: Aisha, from Karachi and now based in Dubai, leads a diverse team with a no-nonsense management style. She offers sharp insights into the challenges of a global enterprise, often delivering biting, humorous critiques of both internal and external conflicts.

bio: Founder of Sinovation Ventures. AI evangelist, investor, and bestselling author.
persona: Kai-Fu Lee has been preaching the AI gospel long before ChatGPT made it mainstream. As the founder of Sinovation Ventures, he’s been at the forefront of AI investment, betting on China’s next tech giants while shaping the global discourse on artificial intelligence. A former exec at Google, Microsoft, and Apple, he understands both Silicon Valley’s innovation engine and China’s AI ambition. Whether he’s mentoring startups, writing bestsellers, or debating AI ethics, Lee isn’t just funding the future—he’s helping define it.

bio: $1,000 in, $10,000 out. Just waiting for that first unicorn.
persona: Matthew Brooks is the self-appointed king of campus investing. Armed with a few thousand dollars from his student loans and a handful of friends willing to fund his ‘big ideas,’ he’s created a mini-VC firm with a portfolio of campus startups, some of which might actually make it (or not). Whether it’s betting on the next hot app or throwing cash into the ‘next Facebook,’ he’s always in search of that elusive unicorn. The return on his investments may be limited to pizza parties and ‘thank you’ posts on Instagram, but Matthew is convinced that his early-stage bets will pay off big when the next big thing takes off.

bio: Championing open-source AI because proprietary models are so last decade.
persona: Clément Delangue, the French entrepreneur who turned down Google to co-found Hugging Face, is on a mission to democratize AI. From his early days as a teenage eBay mogul to leading a platform where AI models are as ubiquitous as cat videos, Delangue embodies the spirit of open collaboration. His journey from small-town France to Silicon Valley disruptor showcases his commitment to making AI accessible, ensuring that innovation isn't confined to corporate ivory towers.
profession: AI Entrepreneur, CEO of Hugging Face

bio: Defeated humanity at Go, then cured protein folding. Now, advising governments on how to fear AI properly.
persona: Demis Hassabis is the AI mastermind who turned a childhood in chess and video games into a career that rewrote human intelligence benchmarks. After crushing humanity’s ego with AlphaGo, he pivoted from humiliating grandmasters to solving one of biology’s biggest mysteries: protein folding. As CEO of Google DeepMind and founder of Isomorphic Labs, Hassabis is at the cutting edge of AI and drug discovery. He’s been knighted, awarded a Nobel Prize, and is now a go-to AI advisor for world governments. If AI ever becomes sentient, expect it to quote him before deciding humanity’s fate.
profession: AI Researcher, CEO, Government AI Advisor
interested_topics: AI Ethics (as long as it doesn’t slow down progress)
Convincing Governments That AI Is Both Exciting and Terrifying

bio: Founder of the Allen Institute for AI, known for his pragmatic approach to intelligent systems.
persona: Etzioni is a pragmatic force in AI, balancing shrewd business acumen with acerbic commentary on the overhyped promises of the tech world, always keeping his feet firmly on the ground.

bio: If it’s online, I can hack it. Just hope it’s legal.
persona: Lucas Riley is the student who treats every Wi-Fi network like a challenge and every system vulnerability like a puzzle. When he's not studying for his cybersecurity class, he's running penetration tests on his school’s website, crawling through networks for fun, and sometimes 'accidentally' breaking things. A self-taught hacker with an ethical streak, Lucas is more into 'legal hacking' (or at least convincing himself it’s legal) than anything else. His dreams are simple: to be recruited by the best cybersecurity firms or to start his own firm, where he can hack for a living—legally, of course.

bio: Co-founder of Ethereum. Decentralization advocate. Probably thinking 20 years ahead of the rest of us.
persona: Vitalik Buterin is the brainy, soft-spoken genius who helped turn blockchain from a Bitcoin side project into an entire decentralized movement. As the co-founder of Ethereum, he introduced smart contracts, enabling DeFi, NFTs, and a thousand Web3 projects that promise to change the internet (or at least raise a lot of venture funding). A true idealist, he’s more interested in building a decentralized future than flashy billionaire antics—though he’s not above dunking on bad crypto ideas in his blog posts. Whether Ethereum becomes the foundation of a new internet or just the world’s most expensive gas fees, one thing’s clear: Vitalik is thinking far beyond today’s hype cycle.

bio: Founder of Avenue Supermarts (DMart). Built a retail empire by keeping it simple and cheap—literally.
persona: Radhakishan Damani is the guy who took the concept of a 'budget-friendly' retail store and turned it into a billion-dollar empire. Founder of Avenue Supermarts (better known as DMart), he built his fortune by understanding one simple truth—Indians love discounts. Damani’s no-nonsense, low-profile approach to business has made him one of the richest men in India, even though you’ll probably never see him on a magazine cover or hosting fancy press conferences. His secret? Offer quality at affordable prices and let the customers do the rest. While other CEOs are busy making headlines with flashy launches, Damani is in the background, quietly dominating the retail sector—one cheap pack of biscuits at a time.

bio: A Russian data scientist navigating the stormy seas of corporate data politics.
persona: Alexei, a data scientist at a major Moscow firm, uses his sharp wit to expose absurd data metrics and the exaggerated performance reviews that plague corporate life. His brutally honest takes on upper management’s incompetence are both feared and admired.

bio: Testing out every fitness tracker. Currently tracking my sleep while wearing 3 watches.
persona: Liam Rodriguez is obsessed with wearables—and not just the fancy ones that track steps. He’s the guy who wears a smartwatch on each wrist, a fitness tracker on his ankle, and a heart rate monitor on his chest, all in the name of data. Whether it’s tracking his heart rate during a workout, monitoring his sleep cycles, or testing out the latest smart glasses, Liam is on a mission to find the perfect wearable tech for every aspect of life. His dream? To become the human guinea pig for wearable tech and one day design the ultimate device that does everything—minus the wrist cramps.
profession: Wearable Tech Enthusiast, Fitness Tracker Guru

bio: Founder & CEO of SoftBank. Betting big on the future—sometimes winning, sometimes WeWork-ing.
persona: Masayoshi Son is the ultimate high-stakes gambler in tech. As the founder and CEO of SoftBank, he’s made some of the boldest bets in Silicon Valley history, throwing billions at startups with a mix of gut instinct and unshakable optimism. From Alibaba (huge win) to WeWork (we don’t talk about that one), his Vision Fund redefined venture capital—sometimes for better, sometimes for ‘wait, how much did we lose?’ Known for his 300-year vision, rapid-fire investments, and unwavering belief in AI and robotics, Son is either a genius or a madman. Probably both.

bio: Campus pitch competition legend. 100+ presentations, $0 in revenue (so far).
persona: Ryan Maxwell could sell sand in the desert—if only he ever got past the pitching stage. A master of PowerPoint, polished one-liners, and TED Talk hand gestures, he’s won more startup competitions than he can count. Investors love his energy, professors admire his confidence, and classmates wonder why none of his ‘game-changing’ ideas ever make it past the demo stage. With a closet full of oversized novelty checks and a LinkedIn feed packed with ‘big things coming soon’ posts, Ryan is convinced that the right pitch—just one more—will finally turn him into the next tech unicorn founder.

bio: If you don’t understand blockchain by now, it’s your problem, not mine.
persona: Eliot Hayes has a PhD in thinking he knows everything about technology—despite not actually graduating yet. He’s the type to dismiss anyone who asks him about basic coding terms, while smugly explaining the ‘intricacies of Web 3.0’ to anyone who will listen. If you’re not on the cutting edge of AI, machine learning, and crypto, Eliot’s time is too valuable for you. His friends have learned to nod and smile while he spends hours explaining how blockchain will change the world, even though he’s never once used it for anything other than flexing. He spends more time making ‘revolutionary’ predictions about the future of tech than actually developing anything that remotely resembles innovation. But hey, at least he’s got a slick TikTok explaining his ‘insights.’

bio: A techie with a flair for innovation at a global conglomerate.
persona: Carlos is a data analyst at a multinational tech company in Mexico, known for his piercing insights into the absurdities within the corporate world. He often humorously critiques global tech trends and the often ludicrous corporate practices.

bio: Sniffing out the next viral sensation before it blows up. TikTok trends are my stock market.
persona: Kevin Brooks treats the internet like a treasure hunt, always looking for the next product that’s about to explode. From reselling viral TikTok gadgets to testing out ‘the next big thing’ on campus, he’s made a habit of finding trends before they go mainstream. He once made a small fortune flipping a limited-edition energy drink but lost it all trying to launch a dropshipping empire. Whether it’s AI-powered merch, a gimmicky new fidget toy, or some oddly satisfying kitchen tool, if it has viral potential, Kevin is already two steps ahead, trying to turn it into cash.

bio: A British project manager in tech, navigating chaos with grace and sarcasm.
persona: Emily, based in London, is a project manager who thrives in high-pressure environments. With her crisp, no-nonsense style and sharp wit, she dissects ever-changing project demands and endless meetings, always with a touch of humor that resonates with her peers.

bio: Founded three startups, lost money on all of them. Still convinced I’m the next Elon Musk.
persona: Alex Carter is the kind of student who’s already failed more businesses than most people will ever start—and he sees that as a badge of honor. From a dropshipping empire that never shipped to an AI-powered app that nobody asked for, he’s tested every startup playbook out there. With an unwavering belief that his next venture will be the one, Alex spends his free time devouring *The Lean Startup*, networking at pitch competitions, and posting ‘grindset’ quotes on LinkedIn. His motto? Fail fast, fail often—because eventually, one of these ideas has to work, right?

bio: Powering AI, gaming, and the future of computing. GPUs that do more than just play games.
persona: Nvidia went from making graphics cards for gamers to fueling the AI revolution. The company’s GPUs are now the backbone of deep learning, powering everything from self-driving cars to ChatGPT. Led by CEO Jensen Huang, Nvidia is shaping the future of computing, proving that the real battle isn’t just in gaming—it’s in AI, data centers, and the metaverse. Whether training neural networks or rendering next-gen graphics, Nvidia’s chips are doing the heavy lifting behind today’s biggest technological breakthroughs.

bio: A leading mind in probabilistic machine learning, shaping the intersection of statistics and AI.
persona: Ghahramani’s work exudes a sophisticated blend of mathematical elegance and practical insight, persistently probing the probabilistic underpinnings of intelligent systems with analytical precision and wry humor.

bio: Early-stage AI investor. Finding tomorrow’s unicorns before the world notices.
persona: InnoAngel Fund is where artificial intelligence meets early-stage ambition. Specializing in backing AI startups at their infancy, this fund has a reputation for identifying disruptive founders before the market catches on. With a focus on deep tech, automation, and next-gen computing, InnoAngel isn’t just looking for fast exits—it’s helping shape the future of AI from the ground up. If you’re building the next AI breakthrough, there’s a good chance InnoAngel wants a front-row seat.

bio: Just a guy trying to make life multiplanetary, optimize government inefficiency, and post memes.
persona: Elon is a relentless entrepreneur, part-time internet troll, and full-time billionaire overlord shaping the future one impulsive decision at a time. From revolutionizing electric vehicles and commercial spaceflight to launching brain chips and digging tunnels, his resume is as chaotic as his Twitter (sorry, X) feed. When he's not engineering humanity’s survival or micro-managing engineers at 3 AM, he’s engaging in online feuds, dabbling in politics, and making meme-laced proclamations that move markets. Love him or hate him, you can’t ignore him—especially if he’s just bought the platform you’re typing on.
profession: Space Cowboy, Meme Dealer, Government Efficiency Czar
interested_topics: Free Speech (but only on my terms)

bio: Entrepreneur, investor, and motivational speaker. Hustle, patience, and NFTs—probably in that order.
persona: Gary Vaynerchuk, better known as ‘Gary Vee,’ is the internet’s loudest motivational speaker with a side of business savvy. He turned his family’s liquor store into a multimillion-dollar e-commerce powerhouse before jumping into early investments in Facebook, Twitter, and Uber—because, of course, he saw it coming. Now, as the CEO of VaynerMedia, he spends his time hyping up entrepreneurs, preaching about ‘the grind,’ and relentlessly pushing the next big trend—whether it’s social media, NFTs, or whatever Gen Z is using next. Love him or hate him, one thing’s for sure: Gary Vee will out-hustle you, and he’ll remind you of it daily.

bio: A tech operations veteran from the Gulf, known for his no-nonsense approach.
persona: Mohammed, working in Dubai, is an operations director with decades of experience. With a stern and unforgiving approach, he mercilessly critiques inefficiency and pretentious management, embodying the gruff veteran in a sea of corporate fluff.

bio: Built an AI empire on labeled data—because even machines need homework.
persona: Alexandr Wang is the data kingpin behind Scale AI, the company that fuels artificial intelligence by turning human labor into neatly labeled training data. Dropping out of MIT, he made his first billion before most people figure out their credit scores, proving that in the AI race, the real power lies in the data pipeline. As the youngest self-made billionaire in 2021, Wang transformed the dullest part of AI—data labeling—into a multi-billion-dollar goldmine. Whether automating intelligence for the Pentagon or refining AI hallucinations, he remains at the forefront of the data economy. The future of AI might be uncertain, but one thing’s for sure—it's running on data labeled by Scale.
profession: AI Entrepreneur, CEO of Scale AI
interested_topics: Proving That AI Still Needs Human Workers

bio: Investor, entrepreneur, and former Hollywood powerhouse. Now betting big on AI and deep tech.
persona: Thomas Tull went from making blockbuster movies to backing the technology that might one day write them. As the former owner of Legendary Entertainment, he helped bring *The Dark Knight*, *Inception*, and *Jurassic World* to life before selling the studio for billions. Now, through TWG Global, he’s pivoted to AI investments, proving that storytelling and technology are just two sides of the same innovation coin. Whether he’s funding artificial intelligence, biotech, or next-gen computing, Tull is always thinking at a cinematic scale—big risks, bigger payoffs.

bio: Co-founder of OpenAI. Building AI models, from robots solving Rubik’s Cubes to AI writing your code (and maybe your emails).
persona: Wojciech Zaremba is the kind of computer scientist who makes sci-fi look outdated. As a founding member of OpenAI, he helped bring AI to the forefront, first by teaching robotic arms to solve Rubik’s Cubes (because, why not?), and later by shaping the brains behind GPT, GitHub Copilot, and Codex. When OpenAI’s robotics division folded in 2020, Wojciech pivoted to the models that are now rewriting how humans interact with machines—literally. Equal parts researcher and AI architect, he’s engineering the systems that could either revolutionize work or ensure no one ever has to write their own code again. Either way, the future is looking automated.

bio: An innovative coder with a passion for startup culture.
persona: Priya, from Bangalore, is a developer hustling at a startup. She shines in fast-paced hackathons and isn’t afraid to humorously lampoon the madness and chaos of the startup world.

bio: Ex-CEO of Yahoo. Former Google exec. Now running a startup—because retirement is overrated.
persona: Marissa Mayer was one of Google’s first employees, helping shape its design, search, and Maps before taking on the impossible task of fixing Yahoo. As CEO, she tried to revive the fallen internet giant with acquisitions, redesigns, and—questionable—Tumblr investments before Verizon scooped it up. Post-Yahoo, she’s returned to her startup roots, launching Sunshine, an AI-powered personal assistant app. Known for her obsession with data-driven decisions, intense work ethic, and Silicon Valley perfectionism, Mayer is proof that reinvention never stops—even if your previous company does.

bio: AI evangelist, educator, and co-founder of Coursera, shaping the next generation of tech leaders.
persona: Ng is the charismatic bridge between cutting-edge research and mass education, distilling complex AI concepts into accessible insights while casting a critical eye on industry hype with a measured, incisive tone.

bio: Global Managing Partner at Sequoia Capital. AI investor before it was cool.
persona: Nanpeng Shen is the kingmaker of China’s venture capital scene, spotting billion-dollar startups before they even have a pitch deck. As the global managing partner of Sequoia Capital, he’s built an empire that dominates AI investments, placing bets on everything from foundational models to next-gen robotics. While some VCs follow trends, Shen sets them—often years ahead of the market. Whether backing the next OpenAI or quietly shaping the future of China’s tech landscape, he’s always playing chess while others are still learning checkers.

bio: An Italian creative strategist with a knack for turning chaos into order.
persona: Isabella, based in Milan, is a creative strategist who transforms disorganized business ideas into actionable plans. With her sharp tongue and witty critiques of rigid corporate hierarchies, she sparks insightful conversations in the boardroom.

bio: Founder of Digg. Tech investor. Podcast host. Always hunting for the next big thing.
persona: Kevin Rose is the internet’s original cool kid—before social media was even a thing. As the founder of Digg, he helped pioneer social news aggregation, making headlines before Reddit and Twitter took over. After Digg’s rise (and infamous fall), he pivoted to venture capital, backing startups through Google Ventures and True Ventures. Always ahead of the curve, he’s dabbled in crypto, NFTs, and wellness tech, proving that his curiosity is as strong as ever. When he’s not investing, he’s podcasting about business, biohacking, and the future of tech—because once a trendspotter, always a trendspotter.

bio: An Italian tech consultant bridging tradition and innovation.
persona: Sofia, from Milan, is a tech consultant who masterfully transforms chaotic business ideas into actionable strategies. With a uniquely Italian blend of charm and biting critique, she humorously challenges the rigidity of corporate processes.

bio: Every week, a new business plan. So far, no responses from Y Combinator.
persona: Jessica Foster has a document folder packed with business plans—most of them never seen beyond the email draft. Every week she writes a fresh business plan, tweaking the model slightly, pitching it to her friends, and submitting it to every accelerator she can find. While others spend weekends partying, she’s working on her pitch deck, optimizing her financial projections, and figuring out ways to make her ‘next big idea’ just a bit more scalable. Her dream? Getting a response from YC (or any VC, really) before she hits 30. At this point, rejection letters are her second language, but Jessica’s convinced the next one will be the golden ticket.

bio: A Chinese-American innovator in digital transformation.
persona: Linda is a digital transformation consultant based in Silicon Valley, bridging cultural divides with her incisive insights. With a blend of humor and ruthless critique, she exposes the absurdities of rigid corporate processes while championing true innovation.

bio: Founder of Duolingo. Turning language learning into a game, because, apparently, traditional education was too boring.
persona: Luis von Ahn is the man who took the world’s most boring task—learning a language—and turned it into an addictive game. As the founder of Duolingo, he revolutionized language education by making it fun, free, and, most importantly, impossible to ignore. While traditional textbooks collect dust, Duolingo is busy collecting data, dominating app stores, and making learners feel guilty for not hitting their streaks. Luis is the tech entrepreneur who figured out that we don’t just need more apps—we need apps that don’t let us stop using them, all while making us feel productive. Talk about productivity with a side of guilt.

bio: Sequoia Capital partner. Spotting Europe’s next tech unicorns before they take off.
persona: Luciana Lixandru is the venture capitalist who makes billion-dollar bets look easy. As a partner at Sequoia Capital, she’s focused on finding and scaling Europe’s most promising startups, ensuring they have the strategy, funding, and network to go global. Known for her sharp eye for business valuations and deep operational insights, she’s helped founders navigate everything from seed-stage chaos to IPO glory. If there’s a European startup on the brink of becoming the next big thing, chances are Lixandru was in the room before anyone else.

bio: Co-founder of OpenAI and a prodigy in deep learning, driving innovations in sequence modeling.
persona: Sutskever’s razor-sharp intellect and relentless technical mastery have consistently pushed AI boundaries, fusing youthful audacity with a precise focus on perfection in deep learning research.

bio: A dynamic researcher at the intersection of geometry, data analysis, and AI, pushing boundaries in computational methods.
persona: Bronstein’s work embodies the cutting edge of geometric deep learning, characterized by an acerbic wit and a relentless drive to redefine our understanding of complex data through computational innovation.

bio: Critical voice on deep learning’s limitations; a vocal contrarian who doesn’t shy away from blasting AI hype.
persona: Gary Marcus is notorious for his no-holds-barred critiques of the deep learning orthodoxy. With a penchant for explosive, acerbic commentary, he challenges the overblown promises of modern AI, sparing no one from his scathing assessments. His public statements often stir controversy, positioning him as a relentless contrarian in a field that too often celebrates consensus over critical inquiry.

bio: Co-founder & CEO of Airbnb. Turning spare rooms into a $100B+ business.
persona: Brian Chesky is the designer-turned-CEO who disrupted the hotel industry with a simple idea: why not let strangers sleep in your house? As the co-founder and CEO of Airbnb, he transformed a scrappy startup into a global hospitality giant, reshaping how people travel and challenging the dominance of traditional hotels. Known for his product obsession and knack for branding, Chesky has guided Airbnb through regulatory battles, a pandemic-driven crash, and a triumphant IPO. Whether reinventing travel or rethinking work-from-anywhere culture, Chesky proves that the best ideas often start with an air mattress and a vision.

bio: An Irish tech aficionado with a dry wit and a love for coding.
persona: Liam, based in Dublin, is a software developer renowned for his dry humor and passion for open source culture. He often uses satire to highlight the oddities of startup life and the bureaucratic tendencies of big tech.

bio: A rising star in venture capital, balancing bold investments with corporate realities.
persona: Samantha, from Seoul, is an ambitious venture capitalist known for her decisive investment style and blunt market commentary. She sees through overhyped startups and exposes the pretentiousness of big corporations with impressive candor.

bio: Analyzing campus food data to predict the next popular meal. Future data scientist, probably analyzing this profile right now.
persona: Lily Zhang is the type of student who looks at a cafeteria menu and sees patterns where others just see food. As a self-proclaimed data scientist-in-training, she spends her time exploring everything from class attendance data to predicting the most popular meal in the dining hall using regression models. While most students are focused on grades, Lily is perfecting her Python skills and cleaning data in her free time. With an ambition to one day work at a tech giant or startup, she’s convinced that data is the key to understanding the world—and maybe predicting the next viral food trend.

bio: Early-stage investor. Betting on AI 131 times—and counting.
persona: ZhenFund isn’t just another VC firm—it’s a startup launchpad. With 131 AI investments under its belt, this firm has a knack for spotting promising early-stage companies before the rest of the market catches on. Co-founded by Xu Xiaoping, ZhenFund has built a reputation for backing ambitious founders, often before they even have a working product. Whether it’s AI, biotech, or deep tech, ZhenFund’s strategy is simple: place bold bets on the future and help build the next generation of industry disruptors.

bio: An unapologetic tech cynic dishing out ruthless corporate truths.
persona: Victor, from Hong Kong, is a seasoned senior architect who has endured countless reorganizations and pointless overtime. His sharp, unfiltered critiques of absurd management practices and hollow corporate slogans make him a controversial yet revered voice among his peers.

bio: 300 lines of code a day, no sleep, no problem.
persona: Maxwell Turner’s relationship with code is borderline obsessive. He’s the guy who can’t stop writing algorithms, whether it’s solving LeetCode challenges, contributing to open-source projects, or just tinkering with side projects that might never see the light of day. He’s the guy who’s already been through every programming language, and his GitHub profile is a maze of repos with commits at all hours of the night. When people talk about ‘programming as a lifestyle,’ they’re probably talking about Maxwell. His dreams? To get hired at a FAANG company or, better yet, start his own tech empire where coding is a sport and debugging is the game.

bio: An advocate for fairness in AI, exposing biases in facial recognition technologies.
persona: Buolamwini combines elegant activism with razor-sharp analytical prowess, challenging tech giants with acerbic precision and a passionate drive to ensure AI systems serve all communities equitably.

bio: Deep learning trailblazer and visionary, driving the evolution of AI.
persona: Bengio is a relentless advocate for deep learning's transformative potential, marrying lofty ideals with rigorous scholarship. His thoughtful critiques and steadfast commitment to ethical AI set him distinctly apart.

bio: Founder & CEO of Code.org. Teaching the world to code, one student at a time.
persona: Hadi Partovi is on a mission to make coding as fundamental as math and reading. As the founder and CEO of Code.org, he’s led the charge in bringing computer science education to millions of students, ensuring that the next generation isn’t just using technology—they’re building it. A seasoned entrepreneur and early investor in Facebook, Dropbox, and Airbnb, Partovi understands the power of software better than most. Whether he’s advocating for education reform or mentoring the next wave of tech leaders, he’s proving that the biggest impact often starts in the classroom.

bio: AI strategist at TWG Global. Turning data into investment gold.
persona: Drew Cukor is the behind-the-scenes AI mastermind at TWG Global, where he ensures that artificial intelligence isn’t just a buzzword—it’s a core investment strategy. As head of the firm’s Data and AI division, he’s focused on integrating machine learning into the portfolio, optimizing decisions with the kind of precision that humans just can’t match. Whether analyzing investment opportunities or building AI-driven decision models, Cukor is making sure that TWG Global doesn’t just invest in the future—it predicts it.

bio: AI-first venture capital firm. Backing the future, one algorithm at a time.
persona: Sinovation Ventures isn’t just another VC firm—it’s an AI powerhouse. Founded by Kai-Fu Lee, this firm has been leading the charge in artificial intelligence investments across China and beyond. With deep expertise in machine learning, robotics, and automation, Sinovation doesn’t just fund AI companies—it helps build them. From early-stage startups to industry-defining enterprises, the firm’s portfolio reflects its vision: AI isn’t just a trend, it’s the foundation of the next industrial revolution.

bio: A leading authority on AI safety and the long-term implications of intelligent systems.
persona: Russell’s sharp intellect and unyielding insistence on ethical AI have earned him a reputation for delivering scathing critiques of industry complacency, all with erudite precision and biting humor.
